questions.question:
Question 1: Which of the following is the method of choice for the purification of highly polluted water on 
a large scale?
questions.explanation:
Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is done for purification of highly polluted water on a 
large scale.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is true regarding chlorination of water?

options.a: Orthotolidine test measures only combined chlorine
options.b: Chlorine acts best when the pH of water is around seven
options.c: It kills bacteria, viruses, spores and slime organisms
options.d: Hypochlorite ions are mainly responsible for its disinfectant activity

questions.explanation:
Chlorine acts best when the pH of water is around seven because of the predominance of the 
hypochlorous acid. Most water sources have a pH around 6.5–7, making chlorination an effective 
form of disinfection. Option A: Orthotolidine test measures both free and combined chlorine in water. Option C: Chlorination kills pathogenic bacteria, but has no effect on spores and certain viruses. Option D: The disinfecting action of chlorine is mainly due to hypochlorous acid.

questions.question:
Question 3: You assign a male health worker at a sub-centre with the task of chlorinating public water 
resources. What is the minimum concentration of free residual chlorine that should be 
maintained for effective chlorination?

options.a: 0.5 mg/litre for a contact period of 1 hour
options.b: 0.5 mg/litre for a contact period of ½ hour
options.c: 0.8 mg/litre for a contact period of 1 hour
options.d: 0.8 mg/litre for a contact period of ½ hour

questions.explanation:
The minimum recommended concentration of free residual chlorine for routine chlorination is 0.5 
mg/litre for a contact period of 1 hour.

questions.question:
Question 4: As an epidemiologist, you are investigating an outbreak of cholera. What is the minimum free 
residual chlorine level that should be maintained in pipelines to prevent further spread of the 546 
Sold by @itachibot outbreak?
questions.explanation:
The minimum level of free residual chlorine to be maintained in pipelines following an outbreak 
of cholera is 0.5 mg/litre. After a disaster (such as a flood), the water bodies are contaminated with sewage and drainage. 
The mixing of faeces in drinking bodies increases the risk of numerous microbial infections. The 
advisable level of free residual chlorine in water bodies after a disaster is, therefore, higher 
i.e. 0.7-0.9 mg/litre.

questions.question:
Question 5: The municipal corporation in your area is performing routine chlorination of drinking water 
supplies. Which of the following statements about chlorination is incorrect?

options.a: Free chlorine is released in water after breakpoint chlorination
options.b: Chlorine demand is the amount needed to kill spores, protozoal cysts and helminthic ova
options.c: 0.5 ppm of free chlorine must be present in water after the breakpoint has been reached
options.d: Contact period of 1 hour is necessary

questions.explanation:
Chlorine demand is the amount of chlorine that is needed to kill bacteria, and to oxidize all the 
organic matter and ammoniacal substances in the water. It is the difference between the amount 
of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a 
specific period of contact (usually 1 hour) at a given temperature and pH of the water. 551 
Sold by @itachibot 0.5 ppm (0.5 mg) of free chlorine must be present in water after the breakpoint has been reached.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following tests identifies free and combined chlorine in water separately?
questions.explanation: Orthotolidine-arsenite test determines both free and combined chlorine in water separately. Orthotolidine test determines free and combined chlorine together. Chick Martin test and Garrod's test are used to test the efficacy of disinfectants.

questions.question:
Question 7: Which of the following compounds is predominantly responsible for the disinfecting property 
of bleaching powder?
questions.explanation:
The disinfectant property of bleaching powder is predominantly due to the action of hypochlorous 
acid. It is 70-80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions. Bleaching powder, also known as chlorinated lime (CaOCl2), has 33 per cent of chlorine in it. 
When chlorine is added to water, there is the formation of hydrochloric and hypochlorous acids. 
The hydrochloric acid is neutralized by the alkalinity of the water. The hypochlorous acid ionizes 
to form hydrogen ions and hypochlorite ions, as follows: H2O + Cl2  HCl + HOCl HOCl  H + OCl

questions.question:
Question 8: 547 
Sold by @itachibot A village health and sanitation team is planning to disinfect 100 wells. Which of the following 
is the most cost-effective method in this scenario?
questions.explanation: Disinfection of wells using bleaching powder is the most widely used and cheapest method.

questions.question:
Question 9: An outbreak of viral hepatitis A has been reported in a village. On investigating, you find a 
contaminated well in the locality to be the source of the outbreak. Which of the following 
methods would you advise for chlorinating the well in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
The double pot method is used for disinfecting wells by chlorination in emergencies like hepatitis 
A outbreak in a village. Double pot method has an inner and outer pot, each with a hole in it and covered with a 
polyethylene foil. The inner pot is filled with bleaching powder and coarse sand. The double pot 
system is then lowered into a well. This device can work satisfactorily for 2 – 3 weeks in small 
wells containing about 4500 litres of water. 552 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: In your community medicine practicals, you are given an apparatus as shown in the image 
given below. Which of the following statements regarding the apparatus is true?

options.a: The indicator used is bromocresol purple
options.c: It is used to estimate free chlorine levels
options.d: It is used to estimate combined chlorine levels

questions.explanation:
The image given is that of a Horrock's apparatus. The indicator used in Horrock's apparatus is 
starch iodide. Horrock's apparatus contains 6 white cups (200 ml each), 1 black cup with a circular mark, 2 
metal spoons with 2 grams of bleaching powder in each, 7 glass stirring rods, 1 special pipette 
and 2 droppers. It is not usful in measuring free and combined chlorine. It estimates the chlorine 
demand of water and is used to calculate the amount of bleaching powder used to disinfect the 
well.

questions.question:
Question 11: What is the amount of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 litres of water if the 4th, 
5th, and 6th cups of a Horrock’s apparatus show distinct blue color?
questions.explanation:
The dose of bleaching powder required is 8 grams. It is given by (n x 2) gms for 455 litres of water, where n is the number of the first cup that shows 
distinct blue color. In this scenario, the dose of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 litres 
of water is (4 x 2) = 8grams.

questions.question:
Question 12: The water sample from a well is tested using Horrock’s apparatus. It is observed that the 3rd 
cup shows a blue color after the addition of the starch-iodine indicator. How much bleaching 
powder will be required to disinfect 2275 litres of the well water?
questions.explanation:
The dose of bleaching powder required is 30 grams. It is given by (n x 2) gms for 455 liters of water, where n is the number of the first cup that shows 
a distinct blue color. In this scenario, the dose of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 liters of water is (3 x 2) = 6 
grams. 553 
Sold by @itachibot Since 2275/455 = 5. The amount of bleaching powder required to disinfect 2275 litres of water = 6 
x 5 = 30 grams.

questions.question:
Question 13: Which of the following agents have residual germicidal effect when used for treatment of 
water?
questions.explanation:
Chlorine has residual germicidal effect when used for treatment of water. UV radiation, ozone gas, iodine and potassium permanganate have good germicidal action but do 
not have residual germicidal effect.

questions.question:
Question 14: 549 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following properties of ozone makes it less suitable for the disinfection of water 
on a large scale?

options.a: Ozone requires a long time period for action
options.d: It has no residual disinfectant action

questions.explanation:
Ozone has no residual disinfectant action. Ozone gas can be used as a primary disinfectant of water in a large scale. Ozone disinfection is 
usually followed by biological filtration or granular activated carbon to prevent further 
contamination during distribution. Chlorine residual treatment is also done as ozone does not 
provide for a residual disinfectant action.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is a lower-pressure membrane process for treatment of water?
questions.explanation:
Microfiltration is a lower-pressure membrane process used for the treatment of water. Membrane processes are employed in the large scale treatment of water. They are classified 
as high-pressure processes and lower-pressure processes. • High-pressure processes: • Reverse osmosis - Rejects monovalent ions and organic molecules of molecular weight > 50 
daltons. It is most commonly used for desalination of brackish water and sea water. The 
membrane pore size is < 0.002 µm. • Nanofiltration - Allows monovalent ions such as sodium or potassium to pass but rejects a high 
proportion of divalent ions like calcium and magnesium and some higher molecular weight 
organics. The membrane pore size ranges from 0.001 – 0.01 µm. • Lower-pressure processes: • Ultrafiltration - Rejects organic molecules of molecular weight > 800 daltons. The membrane 
pore size ranges from 0.002 - 0.003 µm. • Microfiltration - Rejects colloidal and suspended material. It does not separate molecules and is 
usually used before reverse osmosis. The membrane pore size ranges from 0.01 – 12 µm. 554 
Sold by @itachibot Water - III: Water Quality and Standards
